A theory is an idea that has some evidence to support it.
 
 
 "As used in science, a theory is an explanation or model based on observation, experimentation, and reasoning, especially one that has been tested and confirmed as a general principle helping to explain and predict natural phenomena."
 
 
A Law is an idea that has been proved to be true.
 
 
 "A scientific law is a characteristic of the universes that seems fundamental to the workings of the universe."

A hypothesis is an educated thought.

 Much more. A hypothesis displays internal consistency. It is logically formed and must not contain self-contradictory statements. It must have explanatory value. The hypothesis invokes the causes or forces that are at work to produce what is observed to happen. It may not be a mere restatement of the problem. The hypothesis must make an advancement in the state of knowledge - for example, it must explain some observations that other hypotheses have not been able to explain, while at the same time being always consistent with basic laws of science that pertain. And finally, it must be falsifiable - that is it must be vulnerable to being rejected through the use of empirical tests. A hypothesis is predictive and the predictions must be testable.
 
A theory is an idea that has some evidence to support it.

 No. That's the hypothesis. A theory has been tested. That means that from the hypothesis a prediction is made that has the power to falsify the hypothesis. In other words, the prediction must necessarily be true if the hypothesis is correct. Then an experiment is designed and conducted to test the prediction. When the hypothesis has been tested strongly, it is called a theory.
 
 From the evidence a hypothesis is formulated. The hypothesis is a proposed explanation that takes into account all of the observed facts. It is built on previous science, experience and sometimes guess work. Then comes the prediction, followed by the experiment that tests the prediction. If it passes, you may have a theory.
 
A Law is an idea that has been proved to be true.

 Science is always tentative. 
 
 A law is a form of scientific statement with special attributes. First, it is a very general statement in the sense that it is applicable over a wide range of time and space; it is a statement that applies over and over, countless times, in countless situations. Second, the statement of the law, once formulated, does not vary with repitition. Third, and most important, the statement enjoys an extremely small probability of being in error because it has been tested in application countless times by innumerable investigators without once having failed its tests. Laws are not absolute truths.

 In northern Europe and Scandanavia, two species of gull overlap in their range, the herring gull and the lesser black-backed gull. (When I say species, I am using the biological species concept [BSC]. Any two reproductively isolated populations are separate species. If they do not interbreed, they are not the same species). The herring gulls range to the west, while the lesser black-backed gulls range to the east.
 
 You can follow the herring gull to the west, to the Shetland Islands, to the Faroe Islands, to southern Greenland, and on to the upper areas of North America. American herring gulls range well down the coast of North America. This contiguous population continues across North America to Alaska. (I have seen them along the coast of Massachusetts, around inland lakes. I have seen them around Lake Erie and around Lake Yellowstone.) Across the Berring Strait, they are known as Vega herring gulls. As you move to the west, as differences in appearance gradually appear, you will encounter Birula's gull, Heuglin's gull, Siberian lesser black-backed gull and finally, the lesser black-backed bull.
 
 So let me review. These gulls are a contiguous and continuously interbreeding population that circles the globe in the northern hemisphere. At no place is there a break in range that isolates one population from another. So the herring gull and the lesser black-backed bull are the extremes of a single population that circles the globe. And yet, they are separate species.
 
 If you have a problem picturing that, imagine a nest robber in North America that reduces the population of herrings gulls to extinction. You now have two populations of gulls that descended from a single population. They are "cousins", so to speak, and do not interbreed even though they are remnants of a single wide ranging population. So which is the "old species?"
 
 By the way, this is known as a "ring species" in biological science. There are two other well known examples; a salamander the rings the central valley of California, and a bird that rings the Tibetan plateau. In each of these we are able to see the formation of new species because of reproductive isolation - in these cases the extremes of a wide ranging population. When the ends meet because they circle the North Pole, the Tibetan plateau, or the California central valley, they are essentially different species (macroevolution). It must be apparent that they descend from a common ancester - and yet they are separate species.

 However, your definition of evolution is a straw man. While your Little Golden Dictionary may tell you that the word "evolution" means change, it doesn't go far enough. The word has a lot more baggage than that and you risk making yourself look foolish unless you understand the connotations of the word in addition to the denotation. In Victorian England the word "evolution" meant more than just change. If someone had meant change, they would have said change. Evolution meant change in a particular direction, many times with the understanding of progress. Charles Darwin actually used a form of the word (evolved) one time in "On The Origin of Species." It is the last word of the text and Darwin intended exactly the Victorian meaning of the word. However, the word "evolution" applied to Darwin's theories (there are at least 5 separate theories of evolution in "Origin", not to mention other theories of evolution in other books) soon became popular, and was even commonly used by Darwin's fellow scientists. But Darwin objected to the application of the word to his theories specifically because he intended no implication of direction or progress, and in fact, asserted that there was none. But in spite of his objections, and at the urging primarily of T.H. Huxley, even Darwin finally accepted the name "evolution" as the name of the process explained by his theories.
 
 After some decades of debate and objections to evolutionary theory because of the lack of an adequate theory that explained the transmission of characteristics from one generation to the next, Mendel's work was rediscovered. Several biologists, over the course of a decade or more, synthesized Darwinism with Mendelian genetics. Modern biology is built on this synthesis. Interestingly, one major contributor the the synthetic theory was Sir Julian Huxley, the grandson of T.H. Huxley. Out of this synthesis of evolutionary biology also came the definition of evolution that is still used today. I'll give you two paraphrases of that definition, one that I learned when I first began to study evolutionary biology, and another stated in a way that a layman should be able to understand.
 
 Evolution is a change in the frequency of alleles in a population over time.
 
 Quite simple and stated in terms that are understood by every biologist (well, English speaking at least). Now for the layman:
 
 Evolution is a change in the genetic makeup, i.e., the heritable characteristics contained in the genome, either an increase or a decrease, of a group of interbreeding organisms from one generation to the next.

Medical Knowledge and Philosophy
 
 Egyptians believed that disease and death were never natural or inevitable. The most commonly held hypothesis stated that disease was caused by some powerful spirit which might use any means, natural or unnatural, visable or invisable to cause the disease. This was refered to as wekhedu (translated as morbid principle or rot). The medical papyri make specific mention of these things which enter the body from the outside. "The breath of life enters into the right ear and the breath of death enters into the left ear" Ebers papyrus(854f). Another mention is from the Edwin Smith Papyrus (Case 8) "As for something entering from the outside, it means the breath of an outside god or death. It is not an entering of that which is created by his own flesh." 
 
 Egyptian physicians had developed a theory of "metu" (translated as tubes). The metu included blood vessels, arteries, ducts, nerves, tendons and muscles. These tubes ran between the heart and the anus and then went to various parts of the body. In the medical texts the physician often specifies what the particular met (singular form of metu) was carrying, such as blood, air, mucus, urine, semen, water, feces and good or evil spirits. 
 
 In this theory, disease arises when wekhedu travels through the metu. Once inside, it could stick, grow and spread, causing dental problems, stomach cramps, eye infections, fevers, mental illness, tumors and so on. Early scientists and physicians had so closely observed the course of disease they could theorize there was an unseeable thing (wekhedu) that infected the patient (their words "stick, grow and spread"), causing illness. Today we believe that unseen (without a microscope) bacteria and viruses invade the body from the outside, stick, grow and spread, causing illness. Not so different after all.

Ancient surgery was surprisingly successful. There was an excellent chance of recovering from an operation. Several examples exist of cranial surgery, probably to repair skulls smashed during battle. There are only a few examples of trepaning (cutting a hole in the skull for unknown reasons) that are often seen in other ancient cultures. All of those found however, show bone growth around the removed bone section. This indicates that the patients lived after the surgery for some time. Evidence of bone setting, draining cysts, pulling teeth and removal of growths has been found during examination of mummies. A recently examined mummy, found in the necropolis at Thebes, had a delicately carved wooden prosthetic toe complete with toenail to replace one that had been amputated. It had attached to her foot with a fine linen lace. In later periods caesarian sections are attested to by two tomb paintings. There is no evidence of other abdominal surgery. 
 Wounds were treated with willow bark (the original source of asprin) and moldy bread compresses (known to contain antibiotics), kept clean through ritual bathing and infection free through the regular application of honey (known even today as an excellent anti- bacterial). Before operations, patients were given numbing agents including opium and belladonna, as well as others. The knives and scalpels were heated to cauterize wounds which stops bleeding. This provided an (at the time) unknown benefit, sterilized instruments. These facts help put to rest the idea that ancient people's medical knowledge was undeveloped, potentially dangerous and mostly ineffective.

 How old does radiometric dating show the Earth and the Universe to be? Much older than 10 thousand years: about 4.5 billion years for the Earth, and therefore, at least that old for the Universe.
 
 For various reasons (subduction, erosion, volcanism, impact events, etc.), scientists cannot get their hands on the rocks that formed the Earth's original surface. But they do have access to rocks of great antiquity. Using a variety of different radioisotopes to calculate the age of one group of rocks gave consistent results of 3.7 billion year.
 
 
"The oldest rocks exposed on the surface of the earth are 3.5 to 3.8 billion years in age. Consider the various dating methods applied to the Greenland Amitsoq Gneiss: 
 
 Rb-Sr isochron 3.70 +- 0.14 billion years
 Pb-Pb isochron 3.80 +- 0.12 billion years
 U-Pb discordia 3.65 +- 0.05 billion years
 Th-Pb discordia 3.65 +- 0.08 billion years
 Lu-Hf isochron 3.55 +- 0.22 billion years
 
 Note that all of the methods agree (3.68-3.70 is within all of their ranges of error). Isochron and discordia methods also have an internal check which identifies undateable samples. Similar formations which give similar ages can be found as well in North America, India, Russia, Australia, and Africa. This date therefore merits some confidence." 
 (http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/debate-age-of-earth.html) 

 
 To get a better idea of how old the Earth itself (not just its' oldest exposed rocks) is, we need to switch to looking at other bodies in the solar system; ones that unlike the Earth are geologically and meteorologically dead. Two prime candidates are the moon and meteorites. Do the results of applying radiometric dating methods to them produce results consistent with the results obtained using the Earth's oldest exposed rocks? Yes. 
 
 In order to determine the age of a class of meteorites known as carbonaceous chondrites, several groups of scientists measured the age of CAIs (calcium-aluminum-rich inclusions) found in them.
 
 
"In contrast to the relative age dating achieved with 26Al-26Mg radioactive decay, absolute formation ages of CAIs and chondrules may be measured with the 207Pb/206Pb [lead-207/lead-206] chronometer. This lead-lead age is based on radioactive decay of two long-lived radioactive isotopes 235U [uranium-235] and 238U [uranium-238]. The uncertainties of 207Pb/206Pb dates can be as low as 0.5-1.5 My [million years], thus the 207Pb/206Pb chronometer may be suitable for resolving a potential 2-3 My age difference between CAIs and chondrules. C. Allégre, G. Manhes, and C. Göpel (Paris Geophysical Institute) report an impressively precise Pb-Pb age of 4566±2 Ma for CAIs from the Allende CV chondrite." (http://www.psrd.hawaii.edu/Sept02/isotopicAges.html) 

 
 Thus, the calcium-aluminum inclusions contained in the meteorites were radiometrically dated to 4.566 billion years (plus or minus 2 million years). And as science demands, the general results were repeatable.
 
 
"In our recently published paper in Science magazine, we report Pb-Pb isochron ages for two CAIs (E60 and E49) from the CV carbonaceous chondrite Efremovka and a similarly precise Pb isotopic age for chondrules from the CR carbonaceous chondrite Acfer 059. We also report the 26Al-26Mg systematics for the CAI E60. 
 
 The Pb-Pb isochron age for the Acfer 059 chondrules is 4564.7±0.6 Ma. The weighted average Pb-Pb isochron age for the Efremovka CAIs is 4567.2±0.6 Ma." (http://www.psrd.hawaii.edu/Sept02/isotopicAges.html) 

 
 Switching to second candidate for undisturbed rocks, radiometric dating of the oldest lunar rocks produced ages remarkably consistent with the values for the CAIs from meteorites.
 
 

 Description Technique Age (billions of years)
 Apollo 17 Rb-Sr isochron 4.55 +- 0.1 
 Apollo 17 Rb-Sr isochron 4.60 +- 0.1 
 Apollo 17 Rb-Sr isochron 4.49 
 Apollo 17 Rb-Sr isochron 4.43 +- 0.05 
 Apollo 17 Sm-Nd isochron 4.23 +- 0.05 
 Apollo 17 Sm-Nd isochron 4.34 +- 0.05 
 Apollo 16 40Ar/39Ar 4.47 
 Apollo 16 40Ar/39Ar 4.42 
 (http://www.gate.net/~rwms/AgeEarth.html)
 

 
 Sticking with the dating of moon samples for a minute, we can see the high degree of internal consistency produced by applying multiple dating methods to a single sample (note however, that it is not one of the oldest moon rocks). The following table is based on one at http://www.gate.net/~rwms/AgeEarth.html (which itself lists as its reference for this data, "Age of the Earth", G. Brent Dalrymple, 1991). The data pertain to the dating a single moon rock brought back by Apollo 11, sample 10072.
 
 

 Technique Age (billions of years)
 40Ar/39Ar whole rock 3.49 +- 0.05 
 40Ar/39Ar whole rock 3.52 +- 0.04 
 40Ar/39Ar plagioclase 3.57 +- 0.05 
 40Ar/39Ar plagioclase 3.56 +- 0.06 
 40Ar/39Ar ilmenite 3.58 +- 0.05 
 40Ar/39Ar pyroxene 3.55 +- 0.05 
 Rb-Sr isochron 3.57 +- 0.05 
 Sm-Nd isochron 3.57 +- 0.03 
 

 
 So whether radiometrically dating (1) exposed rocks on Earth, (2) basaltic rocks retrieved from the moon, or (3) calcium-aluminum inclusions in meteorites, the results all point to an Earth that is about 4.5 billion years old, and not one of them is consistent, at all, with a Biblically young Earth. Further, not only were multiple objects dated, but multiple methods for calculating were used, and all results produced were found to be consistent.
 
 YECs do not accept such findings, of course; they attempt to dismiss them by challenging the validity of radiometric dating itself (note that, again, instead of supporting their own position, as real scientists do, the YECs attempt to attack the opposing position). 
 
 While scientists openly admit that radiometric dating methods don't give exact ages, the relatively small error ranges are in no way compatible with the Creationists' claims. For example, the uranium-lead radiometric measurement of the Earth's oldest exposed rocks yielded an age of 3.65 billion years, plus or minus 50 million years; this spread in no way allows for the Earth to be just 10,000 years old. Thus these ranges in calculations (plus or minus a few million years) cannot be used by Creationists to reject the scientific conclusion, nor to support their own YEC position.
 
 Very rarely, an anomalous date might be produced by radiometric dating methods. For example, attempts to date a single lava flow that was known to have occurred in 1801 in Hawaii apparently failed: researchers used the decay of potassium into argon but the resulting age was not a mere 100 or 200 years, but 160 million years! Worse, the upper limit was 3 billion years! As one might expect, YECs jumped all over these findings. Might these be legitimate Creationist concerns? No. A single anomalous result dating a recent Hawaiian lava flow, using a single radioisotope, does not invalidate the vast amount of consistent results everywhere else: radiometric dating is accurate, even if a rare exception happened to pop up. For example, concerning the ages of the oldest exposed Earth rocks, in order to double check - no, triple check - no quadruple check - the results, a total of five different radioisotope decay sequences were employed for the same rock formations ... and, all five methods produced results that were extremely consistent with one another. And of course, there is also the fact that radiometric dates were calculated using meteorites, and these too were consistent, both within themselves and with those based on the exposed Earth rocks. And, a slew of radiometric dates based on moon samples were also all internally consistent, as well as being consistent with the multiply checked dates based on meteorites and Earth rocks. The fact that so many different results are all internally consistent, as well as being consistent across the vary different objects dated, tells us something to be sure: the dates are valid. Does a single anomalous result from a measurement of how old a Hawaiian lava flow is show that all of these multiply checked and consistent values are complete rubbish? Of course not. 
 
 One might still feel unsatisfied with the above counter to the Creationist's apparently strong evidence of, though unique, a grossly inaccurate result. Not to worry, just as YECs did and continue to do, I (though for completely different reasons) intentionally left out some details. The fact is that the results of interest were not anomalous: Creationists just made them appear to be.
 
 
"[The Young-Earth Creationist] Morris cited a study by Funkhouser and Norton - "Radiogenic Helium and Argon in Ultramafic Inclusions from Hawaii" published in the Journal of Geophysics Research, vol. 73, pgs. 4601 - 4607. What Morris didn't bother to inform his readers was that the study concerned xenoliths - fragments of foreign rock broken off by the magmas intrusion through the crust. Since they are not completely melted by the magma, they are in fact much older than the lava flow (with K/Ar dating, what you are really dating is how long it has been since the rock solidified from the molten state - at this point the daughter Argon can no longer escape from the rock). That particular study confirmed (as geologists already suspected) that xenoliths could not be properly dated with the K/Ar method. The Funkhouser and Norton study clearly stated that the "ages" determined by K/Ar dating had no geological meaning and also determined that the xenoliths contained excess argon trapped in "air" bubbles inside the rock. Of course there was no mention of these details by Morris or any of the internet postings I have seen that still list this "problem" - despite the fact that Dalrymple answered it over 10 years ago. In the same paper, Dalrymple goes on to describe in detail several other quotes taken out of context by Creationists." (http://www.gate.net/~rwms/AgeEarth.html) 

 
 So the radiometric data stand: the Earth, moon, and older meteorites are all between 4 and 4.5 billion years old.
 
 Note the central importance of radiometric dating to the Creation vs. evolution debate. For example, when using a variety of independent genetic similarities between humans and chimpanzees to try to demonstrate descent from a common ancestor, some Creationists have been known to claim that such a conclusion can only be arrived at if one already assumes that something existed prior to God's creating man (and chimp) about 10,000 years go. To show there is reason to believe that such was the case, a scientist can point to fossils of Australopithecus anamensis, Australopithecus afarensis, Australopithecus africanus, Homo habilis, Homo erectus, and Homo ergaster as being potential ancestors of humans, all of which date back well beyond 10,000 years ago...some to millions of years. But, the Creationist can respond by claiming that those "pre-humans" didn't actually exist that long ago, because radiometric dating methods are completely worthless. Obviously, such an assertion is flawed. When multiple, different radioisotopes are used for dating, each helps establish the validity of the other (besides, geological evidence also confirms that these "pre-humans" lived before modern humans did: their remains are found only in strata lower in the geological column than are the remains of any modern humans).

How old does radiometric dating show the Earth and the Universe to be? Much older than 10 thousand years: about 4.5 billion years for the Earth, and therefore, at least that old for the Universe. ...

 
 In addition to the radiometric data I laid out in my previous post, there is also the fact (which has been brought up previously in this or another recent thread here) that astronomers are detecting light from galaxies that are 10 or more billions of light years distant. This poses a problem for YECs.
 
 According to the Big Bang theory, our Universe began about 13.7 billion years ago. As their telescopes improved over the years, astronomers have been able to peer farther and farther back in time. Many observations have now been made of regions of space that are over 10 billion light years distant. Therefore, it has taken the light from them more than 10 billion years to reach us. But Young-Earth Creationists claim the Universe is only 6 to 10 thousand years old. If that were true, then how could astronomers be seeing objects that are 10 billion light years distant? How could light travel 10 billion light years in only 10 thousand years? YECs often use the same general logic as they do for other phenomena that contradict their religious views: God just did it that way ... He created the Universe mature. 
 
 Since science says that 6,000 years ago there were photons from a galaxy 10 billion light years away headed towards Earth, YECs just claim that when God created those distant stars He also placed some of their photons already en route to the Earth at various distances, making it falsely appear as though a continuous stream of photons has been leaving those stars for the past 10 billion years. In other words, for virtually every star in the Universe, God supposedly, just 6 or 10 thousand years ago, placed some divinely created photons at a distance of 9.999999999999 billion light years away from Earth, another batch of divinely created photons forming this same continuous stream at 9.999999999998 billion light years distant, and few more divinely created photons forming this same continuous stream 9.999999999997 billion light years distant, and so on down the line, all the way to the Earth's surface. So we are now supposedly seeing photons that were created just 6 thousand years ago (divinely created, not by the star) and placed perfectly to create the illusion that the star has been emitting photons for 10 billion years. Actually, God's deceit would require more. For every star that God fabricated a continuous en route photon stream for, He would actually have to had created a billion or trillion such individual streams so that astronomers all over the Earth would see the same false evidence. Why would God go to all of this trouble of planting an astronomical amount of misleading photons all across the Universe, in all directions, making it falsely appear that the stars and galaxies that are billions of light years distant are actually billions of years old? Deceit? Sounds like it to me. 
 
 Let's see if we can easily come up with a satisfactory explanation - besides deceit - that God would have done so. 
 
 Could it be so that plants on Earth could photosynthesize? No, because the Sun is all plants need. They don't require any stars from outside our own solar system, let alone from outside our own galaxy, let alone from outside our own galaxy cluster.
 
 Could it be so that ancient travelers, like Moses, could navigate? No. First, stars and galaxies billions of light years distant are not even visible with the naked eye, so they could not possibly be used for navigation. Second, there are many stars within a 10,000-light-year radius from Earth - which would be visible to the naked eye - that could serve for navigation. Just to give an idea of how close some of the stars in a few main constellations are...
 
 Big Dipper: Those listed on a diagram are 68, 78, 88, 105, and 210 light-years distant. http://www.newton.dep.anl.gov/askasci/ast99/ast99237.htm
 
 Ursa Major: Those listed are 50, 65, 70, 80, 90, and 210 light-years distant.
 http://www.geocities.com/~smalltelescope/constellations/ursamajor/ursamaj2.html
 
 Draco: Those listed are 65, 93, 110, 215, and 400 light-years distant.
 http://starryskies.com/The_sky/constellations/draco.html
 
 Draco: Those listed are 88, 99, 110, 188, 289, 322, 397, 1186, and 1500 - 3500 light-years distant.
 http://www.kyes-world.com/DracoskyPRINTABLE.htm
 
 Ursa Minor: Those listed are 110, 240, and 350 light-years distant.
 http://starryskies.com/The_sky/constellations/ursa_minor.html
 
 Orion: Those listed are 300, 650, 800 (a total of 2 different stars), 1600, and 2000 light-years distant.
 http://starryskies.com/The_sky/constellations/orion.html
 
 So we could find no satisfactory explanation for why God would intentionally deceive the world by planting trillions upon trillions of photons, throughout the entire known Universe, in exactly the arrangement needed to mislead scientists across the globe into believing that stars billions of light years away are billions of years old. 
 
 Furthermore, the YEC explanation is far more involved and complex, and requires more and far greater assumptions, than does the straightforward scientific explanation. So both rational thought and Ockham's razor would have us jettison the religious explanation and accept the scientific one.

 The word quasar comes from "quasi stellar" and refers to small (solar-system size) but extremely energetic sources of energy (output as much energy as large galaxies). More importantly, it is now known that quasars lie at great distances from our own galaxy (the theories that suggested they were local have been discredited by multiple lines of compelling evidence). The key is that quasars only occur at vast distances from the Earth, which means they occurred only in the very distant past: billions of years ago, for example. In fact, the existence of quasars is one line of evidence that discredits the steady-state theory of the Universe: the Universe was different in the distant past than it is now...quasars no longer occur. Quasars fit in nicely with the Big Bang and standard cosmological models that allow for billions of years.
 
 What's the Young-Earth Creationist's explanation for quasars? Well, they can't simply deny that quasars exist.  Penzias and Wilson are credited with discovering the existence of the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMBR). But they weren't looking for it, and, they didn't know what they had found when they did: it was an entirely accidental discovery. Completely independently, a group of physicists had calculated that there should be leftover radiation from the Big Bang and because of the length of time since its release, the radiation should be shifted down into the microwave region of the spectrum. This was a prediction based on the Big Bang theory and was made before any evidence had shown that the CMBR existed. Not until Penzias and Wilson heard of the physicists' calculations did they know what they had found. So the prediction made from Big Bang theory turned out to very nicely match - within just a couple of "degrees" kelvin - what was found independently. The scientific explanation, with its old Universe, hangs together quite well.

Not only does science show that the Earth (and Universe) are mutiple billions of years old (the radiometric data I listed being a real killer for YECs), there's also the fact that YECs' "flood geology" is not supported by geological observations, and is in fact, contradicted by the facts.
 
 Here is what one former-YEC had to say about how geology not only doesn't support "the flood" model, but actually counters it. Emphasis has been added.
 
 
 "Why I left Young-earth Creationism by Glenn R. Morton 
 
 Copyright 2000 by Glenn R. Morton. This may be freely distributed so long as no changes are made to the text and no charges are made to the reader. 
 
 For years I struggled to understand how the geologic data I worked with everyday could be fit into a Biblical perspective. Being a physics major in college I had no geology courses. Thus, as a young Christian, when I was presented with the view that Christians must believe in a young-earth and global flood, I went along willingly. I knew there were problems but I thought I was going to solve them. When I graduated from college with a physics degree, physicists were unemployable since NASA had just laid a bunch of them off. I did graduate work in philosophy and then decided to leave school to support my growing family. Even after a year, physicists were still unemployable. After six months of looking, I finally found work as a geophysicist working for a seismic company. Within a year, I was processing seismic data for Atlantic Richfield. 
 
 This was where I first became exposed to the problems geology presented to the idea of a global flood. I would see extremely thick (30,000 feet) sedimentary layers. One could follow these beds from the surface down to those depths where they were covered by vast thicknesses of sediment. I would see buried mountains which had experienced thousands of feet of erosion, which required time. Yet the sediments in those mountains had to have been deposited by the flood, if it was true. I would see faults that were active early but not late and faults that were active late but not early. I would see karsts and sinkholes (limestone erosion) which occurred during the middle of the sedimentary column (supposedly during the middle of the flood) yet the flood waters would have been saturated in limestone and incapable of dissolving lime. It became clear that more time was needed than the global flood would allow. (See http://www.seg.org/publications/geoarchive/1996/sep-oct/geo6105r1336.pdf for an article showing an example of a deeply buried karst. For a better but bigger (3.4 meg) version of that paper see http://www.netl.doe.gov/publications/proceedings/97/97ng/ng97_pdf/NG4-1.pdf
 
 One also finds erosional canyons buried in the earth. These canyons would require time to excavate, just like the time it takes to erode the Grand Canyon. This picture was downloaded from a site which is now gone from the web. It was 
 http://ic.ucsc.edu/~casey/eart168/3DInterpretation/Deltain3d1.gif
 
 I worked hard over the next few years to solve these problems. I published 20+ items in the Creation Research Society Quarterly. I would listen to ICR, have discussions with people like Slusher, Gish, Austin, Barnes and also discuss things with some of their graduates that I had hired. 
 
 In order to get closer to the data and know it better, with the hope of finding a solution, I changed subdivisions of my work in 1980. I left seismic processing and went into seismic interpretation where I would have to deal with more geologic data. My horror at what I was seeing only increased. There was a major problem; the data I was seeing at work, was not agreeing with what I had been taught as a Christian. Doubts about what I was writing and teaching began to grow. Unfortunately, my fellow young earth creationists were not willing to listen to the problems. No one could give me a model which allowed me to unite into one cloth what I believed on Sunday and what I was forced to believe by the data Monday through Friday. I was living the life of a double-minded man--believing two things. 
 By 1986, the growing doubts about the ability of the widely accepted creationist viewpoints to explain the geologic data led to a nearly 10 year withdrawal from publication. My last young-earth paper was entitled Geologic Challenges to a Young-earth, which I presented as the first paper in the First International Conference on Creationism. It was not well received. Young-earth creationists don't like being told they are wrong. The reaction to the pictures, seismic data, the logic disgusted me. They were more interested in what I sounded like than in the data! ..." (http://home.entouch.net/dmd/gstory.htm)

I'd say the most crushing is the most obvious and simple.
 
 The fact that we can see stars that are farther away than 6000 ly.

I'd say the most crushing is the most obvious and simple.
 
 The fact that we can see stars that are farther away than 6000 ly.

 
 I agree that that is crushing, but actually, not neccesarily to a Young-Earth position. Someone could potentially offer a position where the UNIVERSE is billions of years old, but EARTH is just 6 to 10 thousand years old. That would fit the starlight evidence.
 
 But the radiometrically determined ages of exposed rocks here on Earth, at ~3.5 billion years, is the best direct evidence for an old Earth.
 
 Consider just this one quote.
 
 
"The oldest rocks exposed on the surface of the earth are 3.5 to 3.8 billion years in age. Consider the various dating methods applied to the Greenland Amitsoq Gneiss: 
 
 Rb-Sr isochron 3.70 +- 0.14 billion years
 Pb-Pb isochron 3.80 +- 0.12 billion years
 U-Pb discordia 3.65 +- 0.05 billion years
 Th-Pb discordia 3.65 +- 0.08 billion years
 Lu-Hf isochron 3.55 +- 0.22 billion years
 
 Note that all of the methods agree (3.68-3.70 is within all of their ranges of error). Isochron and discordia methods also have an internal check which identifies undateable samples. Similar formations which give similar ages can be found as well in North America, India, Russia, Australia, and Africa. This date therefore merits some confidence." 
 (http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/debate-age-of-earth.html) 

 
 Not directed at you, but for others who aren't up on this, it is important to stress that the dating methods represented in the above table have internal checks by their very design. For example, a reported isochron-derived age has already passed a validation test because the method uses multiple data points, and checks that all points are collinear (for more details on how this validates the data, and eliminates the need to make a couple basic assumptions used in simpler radiometric dating methods, visit http://www.talkorigins.org/faqs/isochron-dating.html#isochron). This built-in self-check helps ensure that even a single isochron-derived age, such as the one based on Rb-Sr above, is reliable. Confidence in the correctness of that age is increased when a second isochron-derived age (based on a different parent-daughter set of isotopes, such as the Pb-Pb one above), which also has passed its own internal data-consistency check, is consistent with the first. And when a third isochron-derived age (using yet a third set of isotopes, such as the Lu-Hf isochron above), which also passed its own internal validation, is consistent with the other two isochron-derived ages, there is little doubt that confidence in the values is warranted.
 
 That seems like about as clear-cut, ain't-gonna-be-refuted evidence that the Earth is multiple billions of years old, not just 6 to 10 thousand.
